item.title: Stranger Things Fans Blame Netflix For The Bad Dialogue In Season 5
item.content:encoded:
Stranger Things‚Äô fifth and final season is rolling out on Netflix, and it‚Äôs true, something certainly seems stranger than in previous seasons this time around. Viewers of the long-running supernatural coming-of-age drama are arguing that the show‚Äôs writing has taken a massive nosedive, and even as someone who isn‚Äôt actively watching the series, I feel like some of the clips popping up on my social media feeds are not flattering. Fans think a Netflix initiative might be to blame.

Take, for example, these two clips of Noah Schnapp and Finn Wolfhard delivering extremely simple, flavorless dialogue with a seriousness and gravitas the language doesn‚Äôt earn. Some folks attribute the awkwardness of these scenes to the actors‚Äô performances, but others point out that it‚Äôs not just the self-serious delivery that‚Äôs the problem; it‚Äôs that it‚Äôs mixed with dialogue so straightforward that it reads like a mandated plot summary for those who haven‚Äôt been paying attention. 

This dumbing down of dialogue is just one part of the issue; some are also criticizing the uptick in obnoxious quip-driven writing. Some fans are quick to point out that teenagers might believably say cheesy stuff like the kids do in Stranger Things, however, so that‚Äôs more of an ongoing debate. The pushback hasn‚Äôt stopped people from making parodies of the latest season, likening its banter to cringe TikTok speak or MCUisms.

Fans have a theory that this decline in writing quality may have come from a Netflix mandate. In January, N+1 ran a story that detailed initiatives within the streaming company which told creatives to essentially treat the service‚Äôs original programming as if viewers are going to be on their phones scrolling through social media as they watch it. This means dialogue is dumbed down, basic plot points are repeated unnaturally in spoken exchanges, and ideally someone can follow what‚Äôs going on, even if the show doesn‚Äôt have their undivided attention.

It‚Äôs a real shame that Stranger Things might be falling into this trap in its final season, as fans have been waiting nearly a decade for this show to wrap up. Hopefully, the second set of episodes and the eventual finale will fare better when they‚Äôre released on Christmas and New Year‚Äôs Eve. Also, let‚Äôs hope that this doesn‚Äôt end up bleeding into all of the upcoming Warner Bros. projects if Netflix‚Äôs merger goes through.

item.title: Paramount Ready To Spend $108 Billion On Hostile Takeover Of Warner Bros. To Stop Netflix From Having It
item.content:encoded:
We knew Paramount Skydance wanted to buy Warner Bros. Discovery. We knew that they company was pretty pissed when Warner CEO David Zaslav turned down the offer for $20 a share for the entire company. And we knew that this became a fury when Netflix and Warner agreed to a deal at $27.5 per share last week. Now Paramount has reacted, and reacted big. The company has launched a hostile takeover bid, swooping in with a $30 per share offer, which works out to over $108 billion, $25 billion more than Netflix is paying.

It was rumored earlier this year, while Zaslav was making it clear how much he wanted to sell Warner Discovery, that he was looking for $30 per share‚Äîa massive over-valuation of the company, but one he was looking to justify by splitting the company, severing off the ‚ÄúDiscovery‚Äù parts and its loss-making cable networks, and loading that doomed company with all of Warner‚Äôs debts. Paramount‚Äôs opening bid at $20, however, was for the whole shebang. Netflix, however, outbid everyone by agreeing to $27.5 per share after the split, which is due to happen in the second half of 2026.

Now, Paramount is going hard in its efforts to prevent this, increasing its previous offer by an enormous 50 percent, and again for the whole company and all its debt. The BBC reports that the company, backed by the billionaire Ellison family, called this bid a ‚Äúsuperior alternative,‚Äù and clearly one designed to make shareholders revolt if Warner sticks with Netflix‚Äôs lower offer.

This was never likely to go smoothly. If the Netflix deal goes through, it would make the streamer one of the most powerful players in Hollywood, and with the absorption of HBO Max an even more dominant force in streaming. Regulators were absolutely going to be scrutinizing this, and in a time when such bodies are now fully under the control of president Donald Trump‚Äôs mercurial (and self-interested) whims, that could go in any direction. Things were looking positive for Netflix in this regard, after its CEO Ted Sarandos had recently been to the Oval Office, likely to play on the president‚Äôs infantile habit of agreeing with the last confident voice that spoke to him. However, Sunday night Trump gave hints that he was going to be a wrench in the works, saying the deal ‚Äúcould be a problem.‚Äù

It‚Äôs also worth noting that the recent Paramount and Skydance merger only took place after the company, er, ‚Äúsettled‚Äù a legal dispute with Trump by giving him $16 million.

Paramount‚Äôs offer would work out to $108.4 billion for the whole company, including its cable networks, dwarfing Netflix‚Äôs post-debt removal offer of $83 billion. Warner Bros. Discovery isn‚Äôt worth close to either figure‚Äîoptimistically valued at around $10 a share six months ago, and Paramount itself is only worth $11 billion in its own right. Larry Ellison, who backs the company, is said to be worth nearly $270 billion, so could certainly afford it, but it‚Äôd still be the most extraordinary outlay were there to be no external investors involved. As more details come to light from Axios reporter Sara Fischer, it seems that‚Äîinevitably‚Äîa lot of the money will come from wealth funds including Saudi Arabia‚Äôs, Qatar‚Äôs and the UAE‚Äôs, among others.
